title: 6 girls are arranged into two rows. Given that each row contains at least 1 girl, how to find the number of the possible combinations? - Quora

response.answer_text: We have to make some assumptions! Let’s assume that the two rows are distinguishable, with one row being called the front row and the other being called the back row. Then each girl has two possible destinations: front row or back row. This means 2⁶ = 64 possibilities altogether. But we must rule out two of these 64 possibilities (every girl in the front row/every girl in the back row), leaving us with 62 possible combinations.
